body.text: AI chatbots have become increasingly common. How much do you know about how they actually work?

In this brief playable explainer, go through the main stages of building a conversational agent (like ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek). From choosing what type of data it's trained on to what tone it responds in, make the kinds of decisions that go into the development of these technologies. Learn what labour and resources are required behind the scenes, and what capabilities, limitations, and risks they introduce.
Complex chatbots, or "conversational agents" such as ChatGPT, Claude, or DeepSeek, are often powered by large language models (LLMs).
A "language model" is a piece of software that is trained to predict language sequences and generate text responses.

interactiveBody.text: Autocomplete, for example, is a language model that predicts what word or phrase is most statistically likely to be used ________

body.text: STAGE 1: TRAINING

To build a language model, you need training data, or large bodies of text a model finds patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet is a large source of text already written by other people, like forums, books, or research papers. Select your primary training data:

The first thing you‚Äôll need to build a language model is training data, or large bodies of text that a language model looks for patterns in, and produces text based on. The larger the data, the more complex the model's ability to produce appropriate text.
The internet provides a large source of text data, like social media sites, blogs, digital books, or research papers. Select your model's training data below:
Going from massive data to a working model requires extensive power and resources, often at computing hubs called data centers.
This process is very expensive and environmentally costly, using up large amounts of water and energy.
The model can estimate the probability of a character, word, or sequence of words occurring in text based on how commonly it occurred in your data source, and generates new text accordingly.
Pick a sentence, and see what word is most likely to come next:

autocompleteOptions.sentence: At the beach, I played with my ____

body.text: By acquiring information and learning from text patterns in the data, a language model can seem to ramble about a topic.
For example, if you ask: What is your first name?
Based on what typically occurs next in empty online forms, it may respond with: What is your last name?
This is where post-training and fine-tuning come in, to turn the model from sounding like a random text generator to a realistic assistant.
STAGE 2: POST-TRAINING
This process includes high-quality instructions and human feedback, like yours.

You will see a question with two answer options generated by the model, and pick what you think is the better answer. Real chatbots similarly learn patterns from thousands of choices made by humans, often workers.

body.text: In this final step, you can craft your chatbot's "personality" by deciding how it responds to questions. It can sound more like how your friend writes, or your teacher, or your boss. But remember, regardless how friendly or relatable it sounds, the underlying technology will still do the same thing:
Make statistical predictions about what text should come next.
Stage 3: Deployment
You can now interact with a chatbot that generates text based on your previous decisions, like your choice of training data or level of friendliness.
Knowing what goes into building this technology, decide whether you think each question is appropriate to ask a language model.
